feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.summary: Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued September 3 at 12:22AM CDT until September 3 at 3:30AM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of west central Texas, including the following county, McCulloch.
* WHEN...Until 330 AM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1221 AM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen just south of Brady. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Brady, Melvin, Brady Lake, Calf Creek, Camp San Saba, Rochelle, Voca, The Intersection Of Us-190 And Ranch Road 1311 and Us-190 Near The Menard-Mcculloch County Line. - This includes the following Low Water Crossings... South Blackburn between Adkins and 13th, White Street at Live Oak Creek, Hallum Draw, South High between 14th and 15th Streets, FM 1851 crossing Tiger Creek, 17th Street between Pine and College, County Road 120 crossing East Cow Creek, FM 1121 crossing Onion Creek, County Road 124 crossing Saddle Creek and County Road 126 crossing Saddle Creek. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 330 AM CDT EARLY THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued September 2 at 11:41PM CDT until September 3 at 2:45AM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
FFWSJT
The National Weather Service in San Angelo has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Western Concho County in west central Texas...
* Until 245 AM CDT.
* At 1138 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen to the west and north of Eden. Also, 7.5 inches of rain has been reported near Millersview today. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Paint Rock, Eden, Eola, The Intersection Of Us-83 And Ranch Road 765, Vick, The Intersection Of Us-83 And Ranch Road 1929 and The Intersection Of Ranch Road 380 And Ranch Road 381.
This includes the following Low Water Crossings... FM 1929 crossing Fuzzy Creek, County Road 4131 crossing Maverick Creek, County Road 2019 crossing Brady Creek, County Road 4508 crossing Duck Creek, crossings along County Road 4508, County Road 3120 crossing Harden Branch, Highway 380 at Dry Hollow, Highway 380 near FM 1655, Highway 380 crossing and Farm Road 1929 crossing.

cap:parameter.value: NWS: FLASH FLOOD WARNING this area til 2:45 AM CDT. Avoid flooded areas.

National Weather Service: A FLASH FLOOD WARNING is in effect for this area until 2:45 AM CDT. This is a dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued September 2 at 11:35PM CDT until September 3 at 2:45AM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of west central Texas, including the following counties, Callahan, Coke, Concho, Irion, Nolan, Runnels, Taylor and Tom Green.
* WHEN...Until 245 AM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1133 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. The heaviest rainfall has been near Mertzon with around 2 inches. Other areas are seeing 1/2 to 1 inch. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Abilene, San Angelo, Ballinger, Clyde, Winters, Mertzon, Christoval, Maverick, Merkel, Tye, Bronte, Miles, Tuscola, Buffalo Gap, Lawn, Tennyson, Norton, Orient, Rowena and Fort Chadbourne. - This includes Interstate 20 between Mile Markers 266 and 304.
This includes the following Low Water Crossings... Intersections along Buttonwillow Parkway, Intersections along Sammons Street, Howard and Webster, I-20 Frontage Roads west of Clyde, Butternut Underpass, Curry Lane from Clack Street to Catclaw Drive, Southwest Blvd and Loop 306, College Hills and Millbrook, Jackson From Knickerbocker to South Bryant and Texas Avenue at Arnold Boulevard. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Callahan, TX; Coke, TX; Concho, TX; Irion, TX; Nolan, TX; Runnels, TX; Taylor, TX; Tom Green, TX

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued September 2 at 11:22PM CDT until September 3 at 2:30AM CDT by NWS Austin/San Antonio TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of south central Texas, including the following counties, Kendall and Kerr.
* WHEN...Until 230 AM CDT.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Some low-water crossings may become impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1121 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 0.5 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 2 inches are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Kerrville, Comfort, Ingram, Cypress Creek, Old Tunnel State Park, Bankersmith, Waring, Center Point, Sisterdale and Kerrville-Schreiner Park. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 9:52PM MDT until September 3 at 5:00PM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 411 Centennial Mountains and Snake River Range/Targhee National Forest, Fire Weather Zone 413 Caribou Range/Caribou National Forest, Fire Weather Zone 475 East Salmon River Mountains/Salmon National Forest, and Fire Weather Zone 476 Lemhi and Lost River Range/Challis National Forest.
* IMPACTS...New lightning starts are possible, with gusty outflow winds possibly leading to rapid growth of new or existing fires.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered thunderstorms, a mix of wet and dry.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...35 to 45 MPH for the rest of the night and into Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Centennial Mountains and Snake River Range/Targhee NF; Caribou Range/Caribou NF; East Salmon River Mountains/Salmon NF; Lemhi and Lost River Range/Challis NF

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures as low as 35 will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...Northern Oneida County.
* WHEN...Until 9 AM EDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Frost could harm sensitive outdoor vegetation. Sensitive outdoor plants may be killed if left uncovered.

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 9:36PM CDT until September 4 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS North Platte NE
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING CONTINUES FOR THE EASTERN NEBRASKA PANHANDLE AND PORTIONS OF THE WESTERN SANDHILLS TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT FOR STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 204 Eastern Panhandle/Crescent Lake NWR.
* TIMING...Through Tuesday night.
* WINDS...South 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Remaining at or below 60 percent north of Highway 2 tonight, dropping below 15 percent Tuesday afternoon.
* TEMPERATURES...Upper 50s/lower 60s tonight, near 100 degrees on Tuesday.
* LIGHTNING...Not expected.
* IMPACTS...Any fire start will be capable of spreading rapidly and be difficult to control.

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT MDT TUESDAY NIGHT FOR LOW HUMIDITY AND STRONG WINDS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 204

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 2 at 10:10PM EDT until September 3 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents expected.
* WHERE...In North Carolina, Eastern Currituck County. In Virginia, Virginia Beach.
* WHEN...From 8 AM EDT Tuesday through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 3 to 5 ft combined with long period swell will result in rough surf conditions and a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM 8 AM EDT TUESDAY THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 8:02PM MDT until September 4 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING FOR MUCH OF THE WESTERN SD PLAINS THROUGH TUESDAY EVENING...
.Critical or near critical fire weather conditions are expected through tomorrow for much of the western South Dakota plains.
Winds have decreased across much of northeast Wyoming this evening. Therefore, the red flag warning has been allowed to expire. Over western and central South Dakota, a developing low-level jet should allow breezy and gusty winds to continue overnight in many areas, along with limited relative humidity recovery. Although critical fire weather conditions will subside for a period tonight, very dry and gusty conditions should persist, particularly from southwestern to south central South Dakota. Critical fire weather conditions will return to most of the warning area late Tuesday morning and afternoon. As such, the Red Flag Warning for western South Dakota continues through tomorrow evening.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zones 322 Fall River County Area, 324 Eastern Foot Hills, 325 Custer County Plains, 326 Pine Ridge Area, 328 Perkins County, 329 West Central Plains, 330 Ziebach County, 331 Haakon County Area, 332 Badlands Area, 333 Bennett County Area and 334 Mellette and Todd Counties.
* WINDS...South 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 10 percent on Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...The combination of gusty winds and low relative humidity will produce critical fire weather conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Fall River County Area; Eastern Foot Hills; Custer County Plains; Pine Ridge Area; Perkins County; West Central Plains; Ziebach County; Haakon County Area; Badlands Area; Bennett County Area; Mellette and Todd Counties

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL MIDNIGHT MDT /1 AM CDT/ TUESDAY NIGHT FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 322, 324, 325, 326, 328, 329, 330, 331, 332, 333, AND 334

entry.summary:

North Concho River Near Carlsbad affecting Tom Green County.
For the North Concho River...including Carlsbad...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...North Concho River near Carlsbad.
* WHEN...Until early Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding will occur to ranch land along the river. Secondary roads and low water crossings will be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM CDT Monday the stage was 11.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 10.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this evening to a crest of 12.7 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.7 feet on 09/18/1988. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued September 2 at 9:46PM EDT until September 3 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Strong north to south longshore current. There is also a Moderate Risk of rip currents.
* WHERE...In North Carolina, Coastal Pender and Coastal New Hanover Counties. In South Carolina, Coastal Horry and Coastal Georgetown Counties.
* WHEN...From 6 AM EDT Tuesday through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip currents, piers, jetties, and other hazardous areas. It may sweep swimmers off their feet, making it difficult to return to shore.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Northeast winds could gust over 25 mph on the beaches Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Pender; Coastal New Hanover; Coastal Horry; Coastal Georgetown

entry.title: Excessive Heat Watch issued September 2 at 6:31PM PDT until September 6 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerously hot conditions with high temperatures of 104 to 109 degrees possible. High heat risk will impact most of the population and those who are not accustomed to the heat. Low temperatures will be in the upper 70s at the warmest locations.
* WHERE...Indian Wells Valley, Mojave Desert, and Mojave Desert Slopes.
* WHEN...From Wednesday morning through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...Heat related illnesses increase significantly during extreme heat events.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Indian Wells Valley; Mojave Desert Slopes; Mojave Desert

cap:parameter.value: EXCESSIVE HEAT WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY MORNING THROUGH FRIDAY EVENING

entry.title: Heat Advisory issued September 2 at 6:31PM PDT until September 6 at 8:00PM PDT by NWS Hanford CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...High temperatures of 102 to 107 degrees expected. Overnight lows as warm as the upper 70s. Moderate to high heat risk expected.
* WHERE...Central California including the San Joaquin Valley, Sierra Nevada Foothills, and West Side Hills.
* WHEN...From 11 AM Wednesday to 8 PM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures with little overnight relief may cause heat illnesses.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 2 at 8:24PM CDT until September 4 at 12:22AM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Texas...
Rio Grande at Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas affecting Brewster County.
For the Rio Grande...including Rio Grande at Presidio Vehicle Bridge, Rio Grande below Rio Conchos near Presidio, Texas, Rio Grande near Castolon, Texas, Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas, Rio Grande at Rio Grande Village, BBNP, Texas... Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Rio Grande at Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas.
* WHEN...Until early Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet (3.7 meters), the river reaches bankfull, minor lowland flooding occurs, and no significant damage is expected. At 15.0 feet (4.6 meters), flood stage is reached. Moderate lowland flooding begins. Roads that lead to Cottonwood Campground and River Road may flood. Stages are practically synonymous with the gage at Cottonwood Campground at Castolon (CSTT2), and therefore represent the reach from Santa Elena Canyon through Cottonwood Campground, where damage may occur. Cattle also graze in the lowlands, and may be threatened.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:15 PM CDT Monday the stage was 16.0 feet (4.9 meters). - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet (3.7 meters). - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:15 PM CDT Monday was 16.0 feet (4.9 meters). - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 16.5 feet (5.0 meters) just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet (4.6 meters). - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.7 feet (4.8 meters) on 07/23/2024. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 2 at 8:23PM CDT until September 3 at 8:02PM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Texas...
Rio Grande at Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas affecting Brewster County.
Rio Grande at Rio Grande at Presidio Vehicle Bridge affecting Presidio County.
...The Flood Warning is cancelled for the following rivers in Texas...
Rio Grande below Rio Grande below Rio Conchos near Presidio, Texas affecting Presidio County.
For the Rio Grande...including Rio Grande at Presidio Vehicle Bridge, Rio Grande below Rio Conchos near Presidio, Texas, Rio Grande near Castolon, Texas, Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas, Rio Grande at Rio Grande Village, BBNP, Texas... Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Rio Grande at Rio Grande at Presidio Vehicle Bridge.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet (3.7 meters), the river reaches bankfull, after which the flood plain between the levees begins to flood. No damage is expected. At 15.5 feet (4.7 meters), the river reaches minor flood stage, and flooding between the levees occurs. No damage to structures is expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:15 PM CDT Monday the stage was 12.2 feet (3.7 meters). - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet (3.7 meters). - Forecast...The river will fall to 4.4 feet (1.3 meters) early Friday morning. It will then rise to 4.5 feet (1.4 meters) Friday morning. It will fall to 4.3 feet (1.3 meters) Friday evening. It will then rise to 4.5 feet (1.4 meters) early Saturday morning. It will fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 15.5 feet (4.7 meters). - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.6 feet (5.1 meters) on 09/14/2023. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 2 at 8:23PM CDT until September 4 at 10:52AM CDT by NWS Midland/Odessa TX
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Midland/Odessa TX has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Texas...
Rio Grande at Rio Grande near Castolon, Texas affecting Brewster County.
For the Rio Grande...including Rio Grande at Presidio Vehicle Bridge, Rio Grande below Rio Conchos near Presidio, Texas, Rio Grande near Castolon, Texas, Rio Grande at Johnson Ranch near Castolon, Texas, Rio Grande at Rio Grande Village, BBNP, Texas... Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Rio Grande at Rio Grande near Castolon, Texas.
* WHEN...Until late Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet (4.0 meters), the river reaches bankfull, and no significant damage is expected. At 15.0 feet (4.6 meters), the river reaches minor flood stage, and lowland flooding begins. The river begins to flood the road between Santa Elena Canyon and Cottonwood Campground in Big Bend National Park. The river begins to flood the parking lot at Santa Elena Canyon, and cut off the nature trail into the canyon. Campers in Cottonwood Campground need to prepare for possible evacuations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:15 PM CDT Monday the stage was 14.9 feet (4.5 meters). - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet (4.0 meters). - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this evening to a crest of 15.2 feet (4.6 meters) late this evening. It will then fall below flood stage late this evening. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet (4.6 meters). - Flood History...No available flood history. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 2 at 9:04PM EDT until September 6 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Suwannee, Columbia and Gilchrist Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until Friday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Monday the stage was 18.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Friday morning and continue falling to 15.8 feet Monday, September 09. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL FRIDAY MORNING

* WHERE...Neuse River at Smithfield.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Minor flooding begins. Flooding begins along the Neuse Riverwalk. Water nears the base of the holding tank at the water treatment plant.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:15 PM EDT Monday the stage was 15.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:15 PM EDT Monday was 15.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 16.1 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.0 feet on 10/13/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 2 at 3:04PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A low pressure system in Siberia will bring a front to the West Coast providing gusty winds and elevated water. The strongest south/southwest winds will be near gale force from St. Lawrence Island to the Chukchi Sea Coast Tuesday into Wednesday morning before weakening. Sea levels look to rise to about 1 to 2 feet above the normal high tide line on Tuesday night and Wednesday, then recede to normal levels on Thursday.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Baldwin Peninsula; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; St Lawrence Island

cap:parameter.value: Winds and Elevated Water levels for the West Coast Tuesday into Wednesday

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 2 at 3:03PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A low pressure system in Siberia will bring a front to the Chukchi Sea Coast providing gusty winds and elevated water. The strongest south/southwest winds will be approaching gale force with gusts up to 55 mph near Point Hope and Cape Lisburne. Sea levels on south/west facing shorelines look to rise about 1 to 2 feet above the normal high tide line on Tuesday night and Wednesday, then recede to normal levels on Thursday.
Stay tuned to the latest forecast updates at www.weather.gov/afg
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Arctic Coast; Northwest Arctic Coast; Northern Arctic Coast

cap:parameter.value: Winds and Elevated Water levels for the Chukchi Coast and Utqiagvik Tuesday into Wednesday

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 2:22PM MDT until September 3 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Boise ID
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 9 AM MDT /8 AM PDT/ TODAY TO MIDNIGHT MDT /11 PM PDT/ MONDAY NIGHT FOR LIGHTNING FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 400, 401, 402, 403, 420, 421, 423, 424, 426, AND 646...
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 9 AM MDT /8 AM PDT/ TO 9 PM MDT /8 PM PDT/ TODAY FOR LIGHTNING AND WINDS/RH FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 636 AND 637...
.The much-anticipated afternoon round of thunderstorms is developing and storms will continue to move northeast. Scattered lightning and wind gusts to 60 mph are expected. In addition, strong winds and low RH has developed across southern Burns and Vale BLM this afternoon. No changes were made to the warning this afternoon. Storms may continue past midnight across the northern part of the area, generally from Baker Valley east through the Payette and Northern Boise NF, and although unlikely, the warning may need to be extended in that area.
* Thunderstorms...Scattered.
* Outflow Winds...Gusts 40-60 mph.
* Timing...Until midnight MDT /11 PM PDT/ tonight.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Boise BLM; Western Payette National Forest; Eastern Payette National Forest; Northern Boise National Forest; Treasure Valley BLM; Southern Boise/Western Sawtooth NF, including the Camas Prairie; Owyhee Mountains; Western Twin Falls BLM; Southern Highlands; Baker Valley

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 2 at 2:00PM MDT by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
AQAMT
The Montana Department of Environmental Quality has issued an air quality alert for Beaverhead, Deer Lodge, Granite, Lake, Mineral, Missoula, Ravalli, Sanders, and Silver Bow counties in effect until 4 PM 9/3/2024 elevated particulate levels from wildfire smoke This alert will be updated again at 4 PM 9/3/2024.
An Air Quality Alert means that particulates have been trending upwards and that an exceedence of the 24 hour National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) has occurred or may occur in the near future.
As of 2 PM Monday, Particulate levels in Hamilton are Very Unhealthy
As of 2 PM Monday, Particulate levels in Butte and Missoula are Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups
As of 2 PM Monday, Particulate levels in Dillon, Frenchtown, Seeley Lake are Moderate
When air quality is Very Unhealthy... State and local health officials recommend that people with respiratory or heart disease, the elderly, and children should avoid any outdoor activity; everyone else should avoid prolonged exertion.
When air quality is Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups... State and local health officials recommend that people with respiratory or heart disease, the elderly and children should limit prolonged exertion.
When air quality is Moderate... State and local health officials recommend that unusually sensitive people should consider reducing prolonged or heavy exertion.
For more information visit the Montana Department of Environmental Quality at http://todaysair.mtdeq.us
entry.cap:areaDesc: Beaverhead, MT; Deer Lodge, MT; Granite, MT; Lake, MT; Mineral, MT; Missoula, MT; Ravalli, MT; Sanders, MT; Silver Bow, MT

entry.title: Flood Watch issued September 2 at 2:48PM CDT until September 3 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS San Angelo TX
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of west central Texas, including the following counties, Brown, Callahan, Coke, Coleman, Concho, Crockett, Irion, Kimble, Mason, McCulloch, Menard, Nolan, Runnels, San Saba, Schleicher, Sterling, Sutton, Taylor and Tom Green.
* WHEN...Through Tuesday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Showers and thunderstorms will become widespread this afternoon into Tuesday, with multiple rounds of heavy rainfall possible. The heavy rain may result in flooding of roadways, low water crossings, creeks, and rivers. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued September 2 at 1:17PM MDT until September 4 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Salt Lake City has issued a Red Flag Warning for dry thunderstorms and gusty outflow winds, which is in effect until midnight MDT Tuesday night.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 479 Wasatch Mountains.
* IMPACTS...New lightning starts are possible. Gusty outflow winds could bring rapid growth of new or existing fires.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Widely scattered dry thunderstorms.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusty and erratic outflow winds in excess of 45 mph.

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Temperatures in the lower to mid 30s will result in frost formation.
* WHERE...In New York, Southeastern St. Lawrence, Southern Franklin, and Western Essex Counties. In Vermont, Essex County.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued September 2 at 11:09AM CDT by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency has issued an Air Quality Alert for fine particles pollution. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is expected to reach the Red or Unhealthy category.
* WHERE...North central and northwest Minnesota. Including the tribal nations of Leech Lake, Mille Lacs, and Red Lake.
* WHEN...Until 1 AM CDT Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Some members of the general public may experience health effects. Sensitive groups, such as people with lung disease (including asthma), heart disease, and children and older adults, may experience health effects.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Smoke from numerous wildfires across the Saskatchewan province in Canada has been pulled into portions of northern and central Minnesota by northerly winds. High pressure will move into the region and will produce very light winds on Monday. This airmass has become stagnant and heavy ground-level smoke will linger across the northern half of the state for the remainder of the day on Monday. Air quality is expected reach the Red (Unhealthy) AQI category across north central Minnesota. Air quality will reach the Orange (Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups) AQI category for the remainder of the alert area. Winds will become southerly Monday afternoon, and will begin to push the smoke back to the north. Dispersion will improve and smoke levels will gradually decrease beginning in the afternoon. Smoke levels should drop below alert levels by 1 AM Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Koochiching; North Itasca; North Cass; South Itasca; South Cass; Crow Wing; Northern Aitkin; South Aitkin

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 AM CDT TUESDAY

entry.title: Flood Warning issued September 2 at 8:52AM EDT until September 6 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Michigan...
Huron River Near Hamburg affecting Livingston County.
For the Huron River...including Milford, Hamburg, Ann Arbor...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Huron River near Hamburg.
* WHEN...Until Friday morning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:15 AM EDT Monday the stage was 7.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Friday morning and continue falling to 6.6 feet Monday, September 09. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL FRIDAY MORNING
